fields.description:
https://fisheye4.atlassian.com/cru?filter=allOpenReviews

The reviews are listed when browsing as logged in user though.
fields.summary: No reviews displayed when browsing Review Dashboard as not logged in user although counters suggest otherwise

fields.description: We are currently on Crucible version 3.6.3. When we added a new user on prior releases an error message appeared if a non-unique email address had been entered. So now, after entering a non-unique email address and then clicking on Add nothing happens (does not add the user nor does it indicate a problem).
fields.summary: Adding a new user and email is not unique does not give an error

fields.description: It would be great if it were possible to add reviewer names, file names, line numbers and SVN revision for comments into the CSV file. This information might be very useful for some users.
fields.summary: CSV Export: Include more details to the exported file

fields.description:
It would be great if it were possible to configure RSS feed in Crucible to add data like:
* Age details
* Number of files
* Number of comments
fields.summary: Improvements for RSS Feed

fields.description:
h4. Summary
After creating an application link and linking a JIRA issue to a FECRU Review. a user tries to log work to the JIRA issue. The logged work in JIRA gets updated but the Time Remaining does not get updated. Reproduced in JIRA 6.2.6 and 6.3.10, Fisheye 3.4.4. and 3.6.3

The following is the post we see from the FISHEYE logs with debug turned on.
{noformat}2015-03-10 10:26:38,206 200DEBUG [qtp139012355-301 ] fisheye ProfilingServletFilter-logRequest - start request POST /json/cru/CR-3/updateJiraTimeAjax-post?comment=Review%20by%20Brian%20Cruz&timeToSubmit=1h sessionid=n39btwsmaawlw8m2mlhr7z90
2015-03-10 10:26:38,322 DEBUG [qtp139012355-301 ] fisheye ProfilingServletFilter-logRequest - end request in 116ms POST /json/cru/CR-3/updateJiraTimeAjax-post?comment=Review%20by%20Brian%20Cru&timeToSubmit=1h sessionid=n39btwsmaawlw8m2mlhr7z90{noformat}

The JIRA API Function that gets executed is:
{noformat}http://localhost:8080/rest/api/2/issue/<ISSUE_ID>/worklog{noformat}
When we execute this command through CURL both fields logged work and time remaining get updated correctly

h4. Steps to Reproduce
create an appliction link between Fisheye and JIRA
start a review for a Fisheye issue and link a JIRA issue to the review
log time to the jira issue

h4. Expected Results
logged work and remaining time both get updated

h4. Actual Results
logged work gets updated but remaining time remains the same
fields.summary: Logging work to JIRA doesn't update Time Remaining

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In Crucible, when using the comment search, if you perform a search all in lowercase (i.e. foo), it will not find a comment containing uppercase comments (i.e. Foo.)

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a comment in a review with the contents {{FOO}}.
# Perform a comment search and use the string {{foo}}.

h3. Expected Results
The comment containing uppercase characters should be shown.

h3. Actual Results
The comment search is case sensitive, so comments not matching the exact case will not be found.

h3.Workaround
You must match the exact case of the comment to find it.
fields.summary: Crucible Comment Search is Case Sensitive

fields.description:
It'd be nice if it were possible to have code reviewers be anonymous to each other, and also not know the author of the code changes.  (or at least masked)

I've observed that sometimes people behave differently in reviews depending on who else is involved in the review.

Examples:
* The reviewer and author are experiencing "feels" and people go into the review on the wrong footing.
* The other reviewer or author is in a position superior to them in the organizational structure.

This can lead to cases where poor code is committed, and it could have been caught, but nothing was said or acted upon for "reasons".
fields.summary: Allow for anonymous code reviews

fields.description:

After the filter is selected {{scrollDirectlyToCommentImpl}} function is called with {{destinationCommentId}} argument which is assumed to be of string type ({{replace}} function is called upon it) which is not the case in IE (it's integer) and therefore error is thrown. On Chrome {{destinationCommentId}} is a string.

I read all unread comments then. I click Complete again and got You have X unreviewed files message. When I clicked "Click here to view unreviewed files" link nothing changed - the file tree remained the same as it was after clicking View unread comments link.

fields.description:
There are two cases in which reviews objective are set automatically:

h4.Using Smart Commits
The commit message of the commits involved are added as a review objective. This ignores also what's set as default review objectives in the project, so for now I think there's no workaround in this case.

h4.Using Branch Review
Currently, when a branch is chosen for review, if no default review objectives are set for the project, the commit messages of the commits in the branch are added as objectives.

The suggestion is to allow the user to choose among:
* Having the commit messages added as objectives.
* Not having any objectives at all.
* *Possible 3rd option:* add the default objectives as objectives of the review.

*In case the user doesn't want any objectives set at all* the workaround is to set an empty space character as default review objectives in this project.
fields.summary: Default review objectives used inconsistently from branch reviews/smart commits reviews

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
In the {{Add Content to Review}} dialog, if you specify some filters, such as branch, author, etc, they are applied correctly, and the correct commits are shown. If you remove one of them, when you click out of the box, the new filter is not applied. The new filter is only applied when you remove the existing item, and hit {{Enter}}.

h5. Steps to reproduce.
# Create a repository with a new branch, and make a commit to that branch. 
# Switch to the master branch, and make a commit.
# Go to {{Add Content to Review}}. Under {{Branch}}, select the new branch you created. The commit will appear.
# Delete the branch in that box. The commits on {{master}} don't appear unless you hit enter in the {{Branch}} box.

h3. Suggested Solution
The filter should be updated when you change focus.

h3. Workaround 
After you remove a field, hit enter in that box to update that filter.
fields.summary: "Add Content to Review" Fields Should Update On Lost Focus

fields.description:
1. Create a review
2. Go to "Edit Details"
3. Put some text into "Objectives" text field
4. Click on "Help for Wiki syntax", a new "Wiki Markup Tips" window will pop up
5. Press "Esc" key to hide that "Wiki Markup Tips"

Expected:
Only the "Wiki Markup Tips" dialog is canceled, "Edit Details" dialog stays.

Actual:
Both the "Wiki Markup Tips" and "Edit Details" dialogs are canceled. The text entered in objectives field in step 3 is gone.

Similar experience is when you do steps 1 to 3 and press "Esc" key. The "Edit Details" dialog is gone. In case there's some text already entered maybe it should ask for cancel confirmation.
fields.summary: Esc key cancels "Edit Details" when "Wiki Markup Tips" is open

Example of issue that is caused by wrong configuration that is not detected by Crucible:

fields.description:
When file revision is big browser have problems with processing it. It mostly affects IE, because this browser often crashes but reviews with such revisions doesn't work stable also on Firefox and Chrome. 

Only available workaround for now is to split diffs on such revisions to smaller ones and to split reviews to review contained only one (bigger) revision.

Side-by-side diff makes things worse, there's twice much content to handle and IE crashes even faster.

Attachments contains files which may break IE on most machines.   

It would be reasonable to add maximum file limit which can be handled in Crucible view.
fields.summary: Browsers have problem processing big revisions

fields.summary: "Notify" Checkbox to Determine Whether Review Notification is Sent

I created a new review, then added a branch, then tried to remove the branch from the review. I can remove files but would like to remove the branch.

* remove individual commits added by the branch

fields.description:
When linking JIRA issues in review comments for instance, once the issue key is wrapped with quotes it won't be linked to JIRA issue.  This is different from linking another review perm id from review comment, where wrapping perm id with quotes doesn't prevent link to be created.
E.g.
 * test "JIRAPROJ-1: xxx" - this won't be linked to JIRA, while it should
 * test JIRAPROJ-1: xxx - this will be linked to JIRA correctly
 * test "CRUREVIEW-1: xxx" - this will be linked to Crucible review as expected
 * test CRUREVIEW-1: xxx - this will be linked to Crucible review as expected
fields.summary: Allow quotes when linking JIRA issues

fields.description:
I suggest the creation of a document explaining the Review Statistics shown when accessing the Reviews tab at the project's home: [http://localhost:8060/cru/browse/<project_name>]

The statistics are shown as follows:
!reviewstats.png|thumbnail!

The one that caused the suggestion to be made was the *Days to complete* statistic. This metric counts the average time for review when it's in open state (in days). It bases on review changes log and counts changes from last month till "today". So final result is total days count in which reviews were open divided by total count of reviews in that period. 

To further explain a change log, every time a review state is changed (created, opened and so on) the status is saved in the database with a timestamp.

To calculate the metric we fetch status logs from last month; entities are fetched in by date order descending, grouped by Review.
So basically we're getting a list of status updates and we're processing them sequentially. The time difference between opening and closing a review is added to total days variable. The metric will be calculated as a division of this total days variable by the total count of processed reviews.
fields.summary: Document Review Statistics

fields.description:
_Days to complete_ project metic should measure average time in which review is opened (in days). It bases on historical data from last month. 

But it doesn't handle well reviews which in Draft state in that period and counts open time for them as 0.

Calculator also doesn't count whole open period for reviews which were reopened.
fields.summary: Days to complete metics doesn't handle reopened and in draft state reviews

fields.description:
Hi,

I downloaded trial version of crucible 3.7 and installed it.
Then created repository "test2" (the first available from bitbucket) and project "pr".
Then clone this repo to local directory test,

{code:java}
$cd test
$touch TEST_FILE
$echo "TEST content" > TEST_FILE
$hg add TEST_FILE
$crucible.py --repository test2 pr -m "dd"
{code}


and got 

{noformat}
Crucible server: http://macbook-pro.local:8060
Crucible username: test
Please specify a reviewer to be added to the review, or press Enter to continue: 
Error: Failed to anchor the patch to repository test2, please check that the repository is the correct one
{noformat}
fields.summary: Can't anchor new file to specified repository.

fields.description:
Users may want to restructure their repositories so this option should be selected by default since there is no way to retroactively cache repo data yet:

- https://jira.atlassian.com/browse/CRUC-7200
fields.summary: Enable "Store contents of files in review" by default for new Projects

fields.description:
The diff of a review when created using branch reviews is different when created during initial indexing and when the indexing has completed. 

*Steps to reproduce*

# Using the attached [^repo2.dump] create a new repository in FishEye
# While the repository is still indexing, use branch reviews to create a review between {{test_branch}} and {{test_branch_2}}

*Result*

The diff shows more lines added and removed than were actually made on this branch.

!Screen Shot 2015-03-23 at 11.30.43 AM.png|thumbnail!

*Expected Result*

The diff of {{test.txt}} will look like the following which is the result of using branch review after the repository has been fully indexed:

!Screen Shot 2015-03-23 at 11.37.46 AM.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Inconsistent diff when using branch review during initial indexing

fields.description:
For each Crucible project there exists the option to "Store contents of files in review". If selected, the repository can be removed from system without losing file content. 

Given the scenario that a user wants to remove/restructure repositories, if this setting is enabled _after_ reviews are created, the user must visit each file in each review in order to trigger the action to cache the data. This is not feasible for large projects and workarounds aren't elegant.

Develop the functionality to background cache repo data if this option is selected for reviews that already exist.
fields.summary: Cache repo data on "Store contents of files in review"

fields.description:
I am trying to use the REST resource [/rest-service/reviews-v1/search/\{repository\}?path=<value>|https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/crucible.html#rest-service:reviews-v1:search:repository].

*Scenario 1 (that works correctly):*
# Create a review
# Add content using "Browse Changesets" method 
# Select a revision number (in my case, I've chosen #73)
# Click Done.
# Review CR-5 gets created
# Click on the file name on the navigation tree, and this gets displayed:
!Screen Shot 2015-03-20 at 4.41.23 PM.png!
# Access http://localhost:8060/rest-service/reviews-v1/search/SVN?path=trunk/Testing.txt
# XML response includes CR-5:
{code:xml}
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" standalone="yes"?>
<reviews>
	<reviewData>
		.....
		<permaId>
			<id>CR-5</id>
		</permaId>
		<permaIdHistory>CR-5</permaIdHistory>
		<projectKey>CR</projectKey>
		<state>Draft</state>
		<type>REVIEW</type>
	</reviewData>
	<reviewData>
		.....
		<permaId>
			<id>CR-5</id>
		</permaId>
		<permaIdHistory>CR-5</permaIdHistory>
		<projectKey>CR</projectKey>
		<state>Draft</state>
		<type>REVIEW</type>
	</reviewData>
</reviews>
{code}
# This looks correct.

*Scenario 2 (that doesn't work):*
# Create a pre-commit patch from the same repository and same revision #73:
{noformat}
svn diff -r 73:72 file:///Users/fkraemer/Repositories/SVN > /Users/fkraemer/Desktop/svnprecommitpatch.txt
{noformat}
# Create a review
# Add content using "Pre-Commit" method
# Upload the {{/Users/fkraemer/Desktop/svnprecommitpatch.txt}} file
# The uploaded patch will be automatically anchored to the SVN repository
# Click {{Finish Upload}}, then {{Done}}
# Click on the file name on the navigation tree, and this gets displayed:
!Screen Shot 2015-03-20 at 4.55.18 PM.png!
{panel:bgColor=#e3f7fc}
(i)   *Note:*
Here, notice that the file path is exactly the same as the one in review CR-5. 
However: 
# the navigation tree of CR-5 shows {{SVN (trunk)}} above the file name, 
# the navigation tree of CR-6 shows {{svnprecommitpatch.txt}} (which is the pre-commit file name) above the file name.
{panel}
# Access http://localhost:8060/rest-service/reviews-v1/search/SVN?path=trunk/Testing.txt
# The XML response will include CR-5 but *will not include* CR-6. The REST resource is not returning reviews which include files from pre-commit patches.

*Thoughts and Suggestions:*
I realize that the REST resource filters by a repository name, {{SVN}} in my case, and of course pre-commit patches have not been indexed by FishEye/Crucible.

However, if the review in which a pre-commit patch is being reviewed *was able to anchor* the pre-commit patch with the repository, this review could be included in the REST response.
fields.summary: REST API: Search for reviews which include a particular file does not return files in pre-commit patches

fields.description:
h2. Steps to reproduce
# Link a Review CR-1 (Open) to JIRA issue TST-1 (Open)
# Set TST-1 to have Fix Version 1.0
# Use JIRA Blockers Report to search JIRA project key TST and version 1.0
Result: "Issue unresolved, reviews are completed by all reviewers"
# Close TST-1
# Use JIRA Blockers Report to search JIRA project key TST and version 1.0
Result: "Issue resolved, reviews are still open"
# Close CR-1
# Use JIRA Blockers Report to search JIRA project key TST and version 1.0
Result: no Problem result for TST-1
# Reopen CR-1
# Abandoned CR-1
# Use JIRA Blockers Report to search JIRA project key TST and version 1.0
Result: "Issue resolved, reviews are still open"

JIRA Blockers Report detect the Abandoned Review CR-1 as Open
fields.summary: JIRA Blockers Report detect Abandoned Review as Open

fields.description:
When we add patches to crucible reviews that contain renames, like
{code}
diff --git a/two b/three
similarity index 64%
rename from two
rename to three
index 75e1778..15815dd 100644
--- a/two
+++ b/three
@@ -1,8 +1,8 @@
-File two.
+File three.
 This is a
 longer file
{code}
we expect that crucible will display this as a rename, along with the file modifications. Full patch attached.

However it instead shows this only as a modification of the file under the old name; the new name (`three`) doesn't show up anywhere in the review.

We need to review such changes, and we need to do it via patches as crucible basically fails to index our repository, and thus commit-based reviews aren't feasible. Letting the patch describe the move as separate additions and removal makes crucible show it as such, but that doesn't help to actually review the content modifications.
fields.summary: crucible drops the rename in patch files

fields.description:
If a review is created for the first changeset that edits a file in a branch, no diff information is associated with the commit. This can cause issues when reviewing the file as it appears as an entirely new file.

*Steps to Reproduce*

# Create a text file on trunk - Changeset 5
# Modify this file on trunk - Changeset 6
# Create a branch off trunk - Changeset 7
# Edit the test file on the branch - Changeset 8
# Edit the test file again on the branch - Changeset 9
# While the initial indexing process is occurring, attempt to create a review for changeset 8
!pre_index_review.png|thumbnail!

*Expected Result*

When creating the review for changeset 8, it will show the diff information between changeset 7 and 8.

*Workaround*

Wait for the full index to complete or use [branch review|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Adding+content+to+the+review#Addingcontenttothereview-Branches] as this issue has been fixed for it in CRUC-7190
fields.summary: Reviews created for the first commit in a branch do not show diff information if created during indexing

fields.description:
SVN indexing was split into several phases. Last phase (wrapup) is responsible for eg. calculating ancestry between files. When branch review is created before wrapup phase completed it would result in showing in review a full content of file instead of diff to base branch.

It may be especially visibly when using auto update feature as it quickly tries to update branch review without waiting for full indexing to be completed.
fields.summary: Full file visible in branch review instead of diff

fields.description:
h3. Summary
In Crucible, if you have a draft comment with a draft reply, and you go to publish them all using the 'Post Drafts' link, the comments fail to be published.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Create a draft comment.
# Create a draft reply to the draft comment.
# Complete the review and select the 'Post Drafts' link.

h3. Expected Results
The comments should all be published.

h3. Actual Results
The below error is thrown if you try to publish a draft comment containing a draft reply using the 'Post Drafts' link.
{noformat}
An error has occurred
Error
Can't post replies to drafts.
{noformat}

h3. Notes
Seems like Crucible attempts to publish them in wrong order, i.e. attempts to publish reply before the parent comment was published.

h3.Workaround
First publish the draft comment, and then the reply separately.
fields.summary: Unable to Publish Draft Comments if they Contain a Draft Reply Using 'Post Drafts' Link

fields.description:
*Repro*.

I will use *D* to denote a Delete, *N* to denote a 'Nothing' (no actions with the file), *C* to denote a Change and *A* to denote an Add.
Given these notations a AA means that file is added both in left branch and the right branch and DC means the file is deleted in left branch and changed in right.  _Same means changes are the same in two branches and _Diff means the changes are different. For example AA_Same means that the file was added in both branches and content is the same.

We have a total number of 12 possible combinations in 2 branches: DD, DN, DC, ND, NN, NC, CD, CN, CC_Same, CC_Diff, AA_Same, AA_Diff (I have simplified the example, in real life you have 3 ways to resolve the conficts: left, right, manual... but this is already complex enough).

Branch A, we create empty files: DD, DN, DC, ND, NN, NC, CD, CN, CC_Same, CC_Diff

Branch B (from A), we modify files this way:
# Delete files: DD, DN, DC
# Change files:
## CD the content should be 'change'
## CN the content should be 'change'
## CC_Same the content should be 'same'
## CC_Diff the content should be 'diff1'
# Add files:
## AA_Same the content should be 'same'
## AA_Diff the content should be 'diff1'

Lets say this commit has the hash *hash1*.

Branch C (from A), we modify files this way:
# Delete files: DD, ND, CD
# Change files:
## DC the content should be 'change'
## NC the content should be 'change'
## CC_Same the content should be 'same'
## CC_Diff the content should be 'diff2'
# Add files:
## AA_Same the content should be 'same'
## AA_Diff the content should be 'diff2'

Now merge branch B (*hash1*) into C. Lets say this commit has the hash *hash2*. (!3.png|thumbnail!)

{color:red}IMPORTANT{color} you need to make a change, that has not been seen yet (like resolve the conflict with 'diff3'), if you do not do so, crucible will not show your commit (if you find it manually it will say 'No files modified'). (!1.png|thumbnail!)

Add commit *hash2* into review (!1.png|thumbnail!):
instead of all the changes from branch B you see only the 'modifications' you made while resolving the conflict ('diff3').
!2.png|thumbnail!

If you try to force crucible to compare revisions selecting "Diffs to..." in "Add to Review as" dropdown and typing *hash1* in "From revision" field   (!5.png|thumbnail!), the error pops out:
{quote}
Error
Server Error
Error 2
URL: /json/cru/CR-VTBRTLB-3154/editRevisionsAjax/
A java.lang.NullPointerException was encountered
Couldn't find this revision with key AA_Diff.txt@ed346b40b53057803415d69772314ef98f28b4c3 in repository VTBR-TLB_auxiliary
You are running release CR3.6.3 FE3.6.3 (20141229134624 2014-12-29), please report your release number when reporting bugs.
Got a suggestion or an issue?
Discuss it in our forums or visit our support website for other options.
{quote}
!6.png|thumbnail!


*Expected Result*:
review should contain the same stuff that is displayed in SourceTree: 5 files, 2 deleted and 3 changed with proper changes.
!7.png|thumbnail!

fields.description:
With Crucible 3.7.0 crucible.py is no longer able to find a matching repository. I put crucible.py in debug mode and found out that the crucible rest api is returning the 'local' svn repo location rather than the checkout location and when crucible.py is trying to match it will never work.

Our svn repo url is https://shnhost/repositories/myrepo

Our crucible is configured to index from a cloned repo in the local filesystem at /var/svnroot/myrepo, but also has the checkout url configured.

When trying to perform a pre-commit review from a working copy pointing to https://shnhost/repositories/myrepo the crucible.py debug output returns this:
{noformat}
DEBUG:root:Matching remote repository myrepo
DEBUG:root:Matching remote url file:///var/svnroot/myrepo{noformat}

I inspected the API called by crucible.py at http://fisheye/repositories-v1 and it returns this:
{noformat}
</repositories>
<repoData xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:type="svnRepositoryData">
<available>true</available>
<enabled>true</enabled>
<name>myrepo</name>
<type>svn</type>
<path/>
<url>file:///var/svnroot/myrepo</url>
</repoData>
</repositories>
{noformat}

We believe that the url tag returned by the API should be the checkout url (if set) and not the url that fisheye uses to index since none of our developer use that. This used to work so we strongly believe the API behavior has changed.

h4. Possible workaround
It is possible to use [crucible.py {{-r}} option|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/CRUCIBLE/Creating+reviews+from+the+command+line] to directly specify repository
fields.summary: crucible.py not finding matching FishEye repository for Subversion

fields.description:
As a reviewer, I want to mark my progress through a code review as I complete each file. Right now I can only mark the entire review as complete, or add comments to say I'm finished with a file.

The completion percentage shown is inaccurate, as it only requires me to click on all files to be counted as 100%, I don't have to review the file completely or even look at the changes.

Please implement a method to let me check off / mark each file within a review as complete so that I can track progress more accurately than the completion percentage.
fields.summary: Allow marking completion of individual files

fields.description:
What I want from the review coverage report is:
* Show me a graph of how our review coverage is changing over time.
* Let me dig into the detail for a particular period to investigate any unexplained changes.
* Let me forward it to others so they can take a look.

At present it falls down in the following areas:
* It takes a long time for the graph to appear, which is annoying for me.
* It's hard to forward it to others. If I send them a link to the report they have to sit there for several minutes waiting for it to appear. I can take a screenshot and email it but then it's harder to dig into the detail.
Alternatively you maybe could have an "email me the report" button which would email it in html format when it's finished? That would allow me to forward it more easily.
* The detail report has a rather clunky interface. It only allows me to select a day or a week ("week" appearing to mean seven days rather than any concept of working week) and it automatically refreshes every time I change anything rather than waiting until I've finished selecting what I want. It would be much more useable if I could just put in a start and end date and click a "go" button.

fields.description:
h3. Summary

When increasing the "[Maximum Indexable File Size|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Text+file+size+limiting]" setting, if a file bigger than the previous value of the {{Maximum Indexable File Size}} has already been added to at least a Crucible review, the new setting will not be applied to this file.

Even after a re-index of the repository Crucible will still show {{<filename> is too large to show a diff.}} when accessing the file in a review.
h3. Steps to Reproduce
 # Create a Crucible review with a file bigger than the current text file size limit
 # Increase the {{Maximum Indexable File Size}} setting for the repository containing the file or for all repositories
 # Re-index the repository
h3. Expected Results

Crucible will now display the differences of the file.
h3. Actual Results

Crucible does not display the differences of the file and shows:
{noformat}
<filename> is too large to show a diff.

{noformat}
h3. Notes
 * The change is immediately applied to the new files in FishEye.
 * A re-index is required for this setting to be applied to historical (already indexed) files in FishEye.
 * The setting can be applied to a single repository or to all repositories, however this behaviour is independent from where the setting is changed
 * Note, there is no size check implemented for git yet, so this change affects non git repositories only
fields.summary: Max file size limit in Crucible - behaviour for revisions already added to reviews

fields.description:
When editing the details of a review and trying to add a group, if the group has uppercase letters in its name it is not possible to filter by this group name.

The group still shows up in the list, but if there are many groups, due to the size of the list it is not possible to add this group to the review.

*Workaround 1*
Add the reviewers manually one by one to the review, searching for their name.

*Workaround 2*
In {{Administration > Projects}} edit the project in question and, under *Default reviewers* set the users and groups that will be added to the reviews by default when they are created.

*Workaround 3*
Use the [reviewers function|https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/crucible.html#rest-service:reviews-v1:id:reviewers] of the Rest API to add reviewers to a review.
fields.summary: Groups with uppercase letters not found by filter

fields.description:
Currently the reviewcreator plugin allows to add exceptions for certain users, so their commits won't create reviews at all.

The suggestion would be to be able to define, by the moment a user performs a commit, if the review will be created or not (e.g. using some specific word in the commit message, like a smart commit, to avoid the review from being created). 
This is desired because, instead of just adding an exception for a user, sometimes it is necessary to have the review created, but sometimes it is not desirable to have the review created by that same user.
fields.summary: reviewcreator plugin: allow to decide when to or not to create a review

fields.description:
*Problem*
Closing a browser ends the user session. When the user re-opens the browser and accesses Crucible, there is no login prompt and Crucible treats it like an authenticated user. Any page loads after the initial will result in the user being directed to the login page.

*Steps to Reproduce*
* Have Crucible integrated with Crowd SSO
* Log into Crucible with an user from Crowd
* Close the web browser
* Re-open the web browser
** Checking the cookies, the crowd token is gone
* Access Crucible, notice that it returns data as if the user is logged in
** Easier to confirm if anonymous access is disabled
* Reload the page or access a separate Crucible page
* User is redirected back to login page

*Cause*
When the web browser is closed, the Crowd token is cleared, but the not the {{remember}} cookie. It seems that this cookie is used for some checks, making Crucible still return data even if not logged in:
* Attached 2 screenshots of what we see before closing the browser and what we see right after opening the browser (before accessing Crucible).
** Note that browser is not configured to re-open previous sessions
* When access Crucible for the first time, the headers look like this:
{code}
Request Header
Accept	text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Encoding	gzip, deflate
Accept-Language	en-US,en;q=0.5
Connection	keep-alive
Cookie	crucibleprefs1="D%3D1423697357467"; remember=crowdadmin:23:62ca5b2cc3ba57dfa76888e33583f601
Host	localhost:8060
User-Agent	Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.10; rv:34.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/34.0

Response Header
Cache-Control	private
Content-Encoding	gzip
Content-Language	en-US
Content-Length	9239
Content-Type	text/html;charset=UTF-8
Expires	Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 GMT
Server	Jetty(8.1.10.v20130312)
Set-Cookie	remember=crowdadmin:23:62ca5b2cc3ba57dfa76888e33583f601;Path=/;Expires=Thu, 11-Feb-2016 23:29:30 GMT;HttpOnly crucibleprefs1="D%3D1423697370050";Path=/;Expires=Thu, 11-Feb-2016 23:29:30 GMT FESESSIONID=1t7gkorlrltasczw2z0qgg2se;Path=/;HttpOnly atl.xsrf.token.slash=102cc2c85a7162c9e479c2c2cbe39e99d1c2cb6b;Path=/
Vary	Accept-Encoding, User-Agent
X-ASESSIONID	16q2zjr
X-AUSERNAME	crowdadmin
X-UA-Compatible	IE=Edge
{code}
* Notice the the cookie: {{remember=crowdadmin:23:62ca5b2cc3ba57dfa76888e33583f601}}
* Crucible treats this like a logged in user and displays the Crucible page

* When reloading the page, the headers change:
{code}
Request
Accept	text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,*/*;q=0.8
Accept-Encoding	gzip, deflate
Accept-Language	en-US,en;q=0.5
Cache-Control	max-age=0
Connection	keep-alive
Cookie	crucibleprefs1="D%3D1423697370427"; FESESSIONID=1t7gkorlrltasczw2z0qgg2se; atl.xsrf.token.slash=102cc2c85a7162c9e479c2c2cbe39e99d1c2cb6b
Host	localhost:8060
User-Agent	Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.10; rv:34.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/34.0

Response
Content-Encoding	gzip
Content-Language	en-US
Content-Length	9415
Content-Type	text/html;charset=UTF-8
Server	Jetty(8.1.10.v20130312)
Vary	Accept-Encoding, User-Agent
X-ASESSIONID	16q2zjr
X-AUSERNAME	anonymous
X-UA-Compatible	IE=Edge
{code}
* The {{remember}} cookie is gone and user is directed to the login page.
fields.summary: Crucible does not clear all Tokens when Browser is Closed

fields.description:
It would really be nice if a REST API function could be created that accepts as input a JIRA issue and then replaces the "Create Issue" link on a review Comment with a link to the passed in JIRA issue.

Basically, this proposed API function would provide the same functionality as a Comment's "Create Issue", the only difference is that the Jira Issue has already been created and thus is passed in via the API. Crucible takes this JIRA information, and replaces the "Create Issue" link with a link to the specified JIRA issue.  All ofther functionality associated with this link should also be there as if this Issue was manually created from within Crucible.  What I mean by this is that the status of the issue is displayed in the review comment link. This linked issue also shows up in the "Issues Raised From Comments".

Again the functionality being requested for this new REST API function  should be pretty much idential to the manual "Create Issue" functionality.  The only difference is that the API function is providing to Crucible the already created JIRA Issue.

Like other REST API methods, this method would also need to allow for removing the link as well:  GET, PUT/POST,  DELETE

Having the "issue" link on a comment and in the "Issues Raised From Comments" section is very nice.  Creating a review comment link to a JIRA issue via a Rest API function would be a wonderful enhancement.
fields.summary: Expose "Create Issue" like functionality for a review comment as Rest API

fields.description: Crucible review, viewing modified file with '3 lines' view context. If other reviewer adds a comment that is not visible in my context (e.g. 10 lines away from the nearest change), I get information that 1 comment is left unread, but no visual clue as to where the comment is. This is very confusing to users not very familiar with FE/CRU. I guess there should at the very least be some kind of warning that some comments are hidden in the current viewing context. Also, possibly the 'next/previous' comment navigation should ask me if I want to see the hidden comment. Screenshots attached (I saw only two comments, but the file tree on the left side was telling me there are three in the file and one is unread).
fields.summary: Unvisible unread comments if context not adjusted

fields.description:
Crucible macros doesn't support diff nowadays.
[noformat]
Unable to find source-code formatter for language: diff. Available languages are: actionscript, html, java, javascript, none, sql, xhtml, xml
[noformat]


This implementation would be really useful to support code such as:
{code:diff}
diff --git a/file.conf b/file.conf
index be85229..373d2e2 100644
--- a/config/file.conf
+++ b/config/file.conf
@@ -327,8 +327,8 @@ common-func {
   existing code
 
-  # comment removed
+  # comment added
 
   existing code
 }
{code}
fields.summary: Source-code Formatter with diff support.

fields.description: While going through a review using the "j" and "k" shortcuts, or even just linking to a comment (e.g. http://crucible/cru/CR-25700#c156098), Chrome doesn't reliably go to the element desired. This works fine in Firefox.
fields.summary: Anchors to changesets and comments in Crucible in Chrome aren't working

fields.description: Already submitted the feature request in CRUC-6424, which was resolved as "won't fix" on 02/Aug/13. But we still need this valuable feature, so I would like to reopen the discussion.
fields.summary: Crucible patch queue review feature needed.

fields.description: Crucible apparently uses red and green to differentiate between added and removed files for reviews. Myself being colorblind, it's extremely difficult to tell whether the file in question was added or removed. Being able to change the added to a different color to make it easier to differentiate between the two would make Crucible more usable.
fields.summary: Allow color customization for colorblind users

fields.description:
When adding content to a review using the "Choose Branches" option, all branches that ever existed in a SVN repository are listed, even the ones that have already been deleted (e.g., by running {{svn rm branches/xx && svn commit -m 'branch removal'}}).

If the branch was deleted then most likely the work was already merged somewhere (so no one would want to review those changes) or the work was abandoned (still no reason to review that code). Hence, those branches should not be listed.

*Possible workarounds:*
* Configuring a [Start Revision|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Subversion]
* [Adding excludes|https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/FISHEYE/Include+Exclude+paths#IncludeExcludepaths-AddinganExclude]

In both cases, it is required to re-index the repository from scratch.
fields.summary: Branch reviews should not list deleted branches when adding content

fields.description:
In Chrome when viewing a large file (2000+ lines) or files with a large number of comments (20+) in a Crucible review navigating to the different elements (including using {{j}}/{{k}} or the Next/Previous buttons) does not run smoothly and often stops at the incorrect line.

This also affects links directly to comments as they do not scroll to the appropriate place in the source. Clicking on "Comment skipped on line..." will reload the page but not scroll to the comment.

Reproduced using Chrome Version 40.0.2214.94 (64-bit), FishEye 3.7.0
fields.summary: Full context browsing on a large file in a review doesn't operate smoothly in Chrome

fields.description:
The iterative pre-commit reviews are not showing the button *View* (responsible for, among other things, define the visible context) for newly added files - i.e. files not commited to the repository yet.

In the screenshots below it is possible to see this. *file* is an already existing file, while *newtest2* is new.
* Existing file:
!view1.png|thumbnail!
* Newly added file:
!view2.png|thumbnail!

For large files the user is unable to set *full context*, not being able to see all the content of the file.

*Steps to Reproduce*
To reproduce this in order to be able to have iterative patches it is required to include in the patch some file that is already commited to the repo, so Crucible will be able to attach the patch and have 2 iterations.
# Change an existing file.
# Add a new file (svn add).
# Create the first patch.
# Change the existing file again.
# Change the newly added file.
# Create the second patch.
# Create a review, add the first patch, then add the second patch, adding it to the first patch.
fields.summary: Iterative pre-commit reviews no showing the View button for new files

fields.description:
If you copy the link to a comment in a file being reviewed, then try to access this link in a new *Chrome* tab, the correct review and correct file shows up, but the comment might not appear immediately. You will need to scroll up/down in order to find the comment. See:

1. Here I am showing a comment at the top of the main screen and copying the comment link:
!Chrome_Tab1.png!

2. Here I have the copied comment link opened in a second browser tab. Notice that the comment is not visible at all:
!Chrome_Tab2.png!

3. Here I have the copied comment link opened in a third browser tab. Notice that the comment showed up, but not in the same height, comparing to the one shown in the first tab.
!Chrome_Tab3_Wrong.png!

If you try the same steps in *Firefox*, the comment is always visible, and always in the same height. See:
1. Here I am showing a comment at the top of the main screen and copying the comment link:
!Firefox_Tab1.png!

2. Here I have the copied comment link opened in a second browser tab. Notice that the comment is visible, and in the same height of the comment in the first tab:
!Firefox_Tab2.png!

3. No matter how many Firefox browser tabs I open, the comment is always visible and it's always in the same height of the comment in the original tab:
!Firefox_Tab3.png!

This problem seems to be specific to Google Chrome. For instance, the Chorme version is 40.0.2214.94 (64-bit)
fields.summary: Links to comments not working properly in Google Chrome

fields.description:
Crucible currently uses the same permission scheme for Reviews and Snippets, meaning that the same individual / group that can close a Review can close a Snippet, etc.

This should be more flexible, allowing, for example, only Moderators to close Reviews, but only the Author to close Snippets created by him.
fields.summary: Separate Snippet and Review permission scheme

fields.description:
When the version of a file in a review is outdated currently this is shown via a an extra option in the diffControls menu;

!Screen Shot 2015-02-05 at 12.38.23.png|thumbnail!

This could be made clearer to the user in order to ensure they are made aware of the fact the file is out of date. 

More so - inline with CRUC-5869 make the user aware that there are outdated files in the review without the need to select the file.
fields.summary: Improve notification method for when a file is outdated in a Review

fields.description:
When adding a changeset to a review, if the changeset has no commit message then a NullPointerException is received;

!Screen Shot 2015-02-03 at 14.35.39.png|thumbnail!

h4. Steps to reproduce;

# Perform a commit without a message
# Create a Review
# Try to add the changeset that contains no commit message
# NullPointerException error retrieved.

Tested and confirmed with subversion.

The workaround is simply to add a message when performing the commit.
fields.summary: NPE when adding a changest to a review with no commit message from a SVN Repo

fields.description:
h3.Steps to reproduce
# Commit a file with 10 lines to SVN repo (eg: revision 1)
# Edit line 1 of the file
# Create a SVN diff patch (revision 1 and working copy)
# Add the patch to a review (eg: CR-1)
# Edit line 10 of the file
# Commit the file (eg: revision 2)
# Edit line 2 of the file
# Create a SVN diff patch (revision 2 and working copy)
# Add the patch to the same review as iterative changes (CR-1)
The diff in the review (CR-1) between revision 1 and iterative 2 showing changes in line 1, 2 and 10 even though the two patches have only changes in line 1 and 2.
Since the second patch is anchored to revision 2, the revision 2 is added as a hidden revision between iterative 1 and iterative 2.

It would be better if the Crucible diff can have different colour between changes in patch (line 1 and 2) and changes in the hidden revision (line 10).
fields.summary: Different diff colour between patch and revision

fields.description:
Currently the [function /share|https://docs.atlassian.com/fisheye-crucible/latest/wadl/fecru.html#rest-service-fecru:share-content-v1:share] of the Rest API allows to share reviews, but user needs to use the actual ID of the review, not the perm ID (which is seen in the UI). 

The suggestion is to allow using the perm ID with this function, so user doesn't need to go after the actual ID of the review.
fields.summary: Allow /share of the Rest API to accept perm ID for reviews
